subject: fw-update: Implement firmware update package parser
commitMessage:
fw-update: Implement firmware update package parser

PackageParser implements parsing the common elements across version
1 and version 2 of the PackageHeader. PackageParserV1 handles parsing
the package header version 1 as defined in DSP0267_1.0.0 and
DSP0267_1.0.1.

Tested: Unit tests added

Signed-off-by: Tom Joseph <rushtotom@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Iddabd435755f462c042a85a286b1b0a50eb346b1

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 1630f399b27907f0473fb3e722c71dfc0e0c204f by Tom Joseph
Can we assign this safely to size_t ?
yup, spec assigns 2 bytes for the header, we are going beyond that.

this logic will not work for PLDM packages where they maintain some gap in between components.
Eg: Let us assume 
package header size : 200 bytes
some gap 10 bytes
component 1 size 300 bytes(compLocOffset : 210)
some gap 10 bytes
component 2 size 400 bytes(compLocOffset : 520)
some gap 10 bytes
component 1 size 300 bytes(compLocOffset : 930)
some gap 10 bytes
Total package size 1240
Why are the gaps maintained?

There could be multiple reasons.
One of the reasons will be
We have many variable fields in the package which can be increased or decreased form version to version. Same for the component sizes as well they could increase or decrease from version to version.
Irrespective of these to maintain constant package size(total package size) some buffer can be allowed in between.

> We have many variable fields in the package which can be increased or decreased form version to version. Same for the component sizes as well they could increase or decrease from version to version. Irrespective of these to maintain constant package size(total package size) some buffer can be allowed in between.

What will be the merit to maintain a constant package size? If there is a new firmware image(component) in the package, the package needs to be rebuilt including the header because the size needs to be updated in the header. We can use tools like this to build packages(https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/tree/master/tools/fw-update).

Atleast PLDM DSP0267 doesn't restrict putting buffers, but PLDM FW update package expects Comp1 followed by Comp2.. and so on.

Why are we not using typedefs defined in common/type.hpp in this file?
Example. using ComponentBitmapBitLength = uint16_t;
Ack

What's the benefit of this check? Why is pkgSize more reliable?

This check is to verify whether the package header size mentioned in the Package header information in parsePkgHeader(...) matches with what is read from the package. For example the package header could tell 100 bytes of header, but what is in the package could be much less <100 bytes, in which this condition will catch.
Will you be pushing new commits to report failures like these as events that can be seen over an OOB API?
Yes, all these errors will translate to message registry event from the UpdateService schema.
This local method seems unused.
This will be used in the UpdateManager patch to figure the Package Header version and parse accordingly.
Can avoid a sting copy here.
